title: Hi, I have been doing research about this font, but still got no clue. It would be great if someone come across what this font is, thank you very much :) Keith
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402035144im_/http:/typophile.com/files/as2_font_0_6496.jpg)

Hi, I have been doing research about this font, but still got no clue. It would be great if someone come across what this font is, thank you very much :) Keith
author: keithluc

comments.content:
It feels [DIN](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402035144/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontfont/ff-din) Black Italic but some details are off: /&, /J leg terminal... Closest I have is [Ciutadella](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402035144/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/emtype/ciutadella). What's the sample origin?  
More alternatives so far: [Kelson Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402035144/http:/fontfabric.com/kelson-sans), [Abel](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402035144/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/madtype/abel-pro) (manually slanted), [Helsinki](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402035144/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ludwiguebele/helsinki) (not bad but wrong /&), [Nudista](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402035144/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/suitcase/nudista)

Thanks Ryuk!!! Very appreciated your help!!! But I think that image just combined with some different fonts.. cos i have try using Din it's quite match with that but some letters like A, M, J, don't mate with the image. But thanks and you have been helping me a lot! thanks! :)

Try [Robusta Heavy Italic](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402035144/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/tilde/robusta-pro/heavy-italic/glyphs.html) the /& symbol is correct and the other characters seem right too. Its also slanted
Sorry but Robusta does not look to fit at all to me: /O, /R leg, /&, /J leg terminal... Actually, everything :D
Flama Black Italic with a reduced sized ampersand
its either geogrotesque or something super similar
Good call, Les! Looks almost perfectly matching for the lettering. The ampersand is still off.

Fun game. Anyone can play. Slant Flama Bold Italic 10 degrees in Fontshop and the sloped vertical strokes on LEKRBFP etc. become precisely vertical. Slant the original image 10 degrees in your graphics program for comparison. Try the game with some of the other font candidates. Most of them do not have a slant of exactly 10 degrees and the mismatch becomes obvious.  
Don

Perfect Les! And my apologies for the question, I checked Flama at [Village](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402035144/http:/typophile.com/wiki/https%3A/%252Fvllg.com/feliciano/flama/sets). The italic glyph set is not shown and the typetester shows a different /&. [Feliciano](http://web.archive.org/web/20150402035144/http:/www.felicianotypefoundry.com/cms/fonts/flama?page=5) shows the right set. So, again, sorry for the confusion. Flama it is!
